awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Summer Integrative Neuroscience Experience (SINE) in Jupiter
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to Florida Atlantic  University (FAU), located in Jupiter, FL will support the training of 10 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2020-2022.  Students will have the opportunity to work in laboratories at FAU, Scripps-Florida and the Max Plank-Florida Institute on research that focuses on a range of neuroscience projects, including synaptic function, behavioral pharmacology, neurogenetics and systems neuroscience. Students will participate in workshops that provide a broad background in scientific communication, research approaches, and responsible conduct in research.  Students will be selected based on academic merit, and potential for success in research, with the goal of recruiting under-represented minorities (URM), first generation college students, and those from non-research intensive institutions. Formal mentoring will continue beyond the completion of the summer internship to provide support for those students interested in pursuing graduate school, industry positions, or other science-related opportunities. Taken together, this summer program will provide students an integrative experience that will support the pursuit of research-oriented careers in neuroscience.

 It is anticipated that a total of 30 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities, will be trained in the program. Students will learn how research is conducted, enhance their lab skills, and learn concepts in neuroscience. Many will present the results of their work at scientific conferences including the summer undergraduate research symposium.  Students will also interact with other REU programs at FAU and Scripps and engage in scientific networking activites throughout the summer. A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU Site programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program.  Formative and summative assessments will be done to determine student perception of career goals, research experience, and confidence in different science areas, i.e. research, microscopy, statistics, presentation. Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine their career paths. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information about the program is available at  http://www.fau.edu/jupiter/reu-program.php or  by contacting the PI (Dr. Alex Keene at Keene@FAU.edu) or the co-PI (Dr. Stackman at rstackma@fau.edu).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
The REU Site Renewal Award at the FAU Jupiter campus supported training for ten students annually over a ten-week summer period in laboratories at FAU Jupiter Life Science Labs and Stiles-Nicholson Brain Institute, along with campus neighbors at the Max Planck Florida Institute, UF-Scripps, and the Zeiss Microscopy Solutions Center. Neuroscience was a rapidly growing area in Florida for research, and the Jupiter campus, with its three institutes on a shared campus, provided an extraordinary environment with state-of-the-art research technologies and world-class training opportunities for undergraduates. These institutes housed 30 neuroscience laboratories studying neurophysiology, neurodevelopment, behavioral genetics, neuropsychiatric disorders, and more. Each student was assigned a PI with aligned research interests and an academic mentor to offer career guidance during and after the REU experience, alongside participation in a workshop series. Students were selected based on academic performance, research experience, and potential for success in research. FAU leveraged its connections with other US institutions and focused on recruiting underrepresented, first-generation college students, and those with limited access to research opportunities.

The neuroscience community in Jupiter offered a unique REU site, combining academic institutes (FAU and UF-Scripps) and a non-profit research institute (Max Planck) to deliver world-class training in brain sciences. This community provided broad neuroscience research opportunities using shared equipment and resources within an integrated training program. FAU had an established undergraduate neuroscience program whose faculty and staff specialized in advising, scientific presentation, and microscopy. Experts in Jupiter directed components of the REU, which extended beyond laboratory skill development to include exposure to diverse neuroscience research areas and career advising. The program’s implementation encompassed research activities, advising, and a neuroscience workshop series emphasizing scientific presentation and critical thinking, creating a comprehensive summer experience for those interested in scientific research and graduate studies.

Broader Impacts: The SINE REU continued to foster scientific interest among underrepresented and first-generation college students, encouraging neuroscience and life sciences as career paths. Recruitment attracted highly qualified undergraduates from minority-serving institutions. A poster symposium held at the end of the REU was open to the public and students from local universities.To support similar programs beyond FAU, the entire curriculum developed from this program was made readily available on the canvas website and available by request.

 


Last Modified: 11/12/2024
Modified by: Bethany A Stanhope
